clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Obstructive Sleep Apnea and/or Cigarette Smoking on Endothelial Function
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Intermittent Hypoxia and/or Cigarette Smoking on Endothelial Injury in Vivo - Relevance to Obstructive Sleep Apnea

brief_summary.textblock: The hypothesis of this study is that either obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) or cigarette smoking (CS) exposure would produce oxidative stress and inflammation leading to endothelial injury, and the combined exposure would be additive or synergistic.

primary_outcome.measure: reactive hyperemia induced peripheral arterial tone (RH-RAT) index

secondary_outcome.measure: circulatory metabolic and vascular inflammatory biomarkers

arm_group.description: subjects who smoke either in the past or currently, with confirmed moderate-severe OSA

arm_group.arm_group_label: smoker, mild OSA or without OSA
arm_group.description: subjects who smoke either in the past or currently, with mild OSA or without OSA
subjects who never smoke, with confirmed moderate-severe OSA

arm_group.arm_group_label: nonsmoker, with mild OSA or without OSA
arm_group.description: subjects who never smoke, with mild OSA or without OSA

study_pop.textblock: Consecutive subjects who undergo polysomnograms (PSG) in the Sleep Disorder Centre, Department of Medicine, Queen Mary Hospital, and who fulfill the study criteria will be recruited.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- No acute illness
- No hospitalization in past 4 weeks
- Absence of medical comorbidity such as hypertension, ischemic heart disease, diabetes and hyperlipidemia, renal impairment, vasculitis or Raynaud's syndrome, peripheral vascular disease especially Buerger's disease, aortic disease (aortic aneurysm or dilatation), cancer, thrombocytopenia, coagulation disorder or other chronic medical illness
Exclusion Criteria:
- Mentally incapacitated
